body.p:
Your various letters received here between the 20th
April last and 5th June did not meet my sight until the latter date,
on my return from a voyage to St. Thomas Curaçao during those
6 weeks. My tour was ostensibly to see my brother off. We had not set
eyes on one another for 14? years, during which time he had got married,
but his wife, like mine, is עקרה. Prior to my departure, the Congregational ruler
of St. Thomas had invited me to permit them to put forth my name as a candidate
fro the vacant situation of minister, which I prudently declined; as is the
event of the Congregation's refusal to elect me, my position here would have
been injured. On my arrival at St. Thomas, the rulers invited me to meet
them, and, after that interview took action. After I sailed (3 days after) the interview for
Curaçao. A meeting of the voting members was called in my absence and two propositions
were submitted for their decision. The first, to raise the salary from $1200, the amount of stipend advertised, to $1800; which was carried, 10 only dissenting,
and they, only on the plea that the congregation could not afford the larger
sum. The second, to elect a minister. The President proposed me, adding
that he had not my permission, but hoping that the expression of the
member, in my favour, might induce me to accept. The proposition was
carried without a dissenting voice. The second day after my arrival, a
deputation waited upon me with a numerously and respectably signed
address, inviting me to stay a fortnight longer, before going to Curaçao. I was
obliged to decline, but, to soften the refusal, read and preached for in the
Synagogue on Friday night the 1st May. The next morning I embarked
on my return from Curaçao in the 20th May, I stayed at St. Thomas

p.rend: The following is written in the top right.

body.p:
till the 1st June; and on מוסף read שחרית and preached again.
Each time the Synagogue was filled. My reception in both places was
gratifying in the extreme. Now about Curaçao. ?
is a generous, charitable man, of large proportions and with a
larger heart. In five minutes we understood each other perfectly. We had
many discussions on various Jewish subjects, Scriptural, Rabbinical,
Synagogal, raised, I suppose, for the purpose of drawing me out.
Books were introduced, and many a hard passage in משנה דינים מפרשים
was submitted for my opinion. Whether I acquitted myself will or ill, I cannot
say; but I am sure you will be pleased to hear that the Chactaeu?, when he
came to accompany me to the vessel, presented me with a מדרשים in
Hebrew & English, conferring on me the rank and title of תעודה and,
calling upon all congregations to acknowledge and receive me as such.
I suppose you know his title is Opper Rattiner?, or Chief Rabbi. He
teaches extemporaneously, much in the style of Plessner, illustrating his
discourse copiously from midrash. He asked me to give him a test one
Sabbath just before the sermon was to be delivered, and I selected Prov. XVIII.I.
on which he discoursed for about 30 minutes, in Dutch. I was told by good
judges it was an able exposition, but, tho' I understood parts here and there,
I cannot say anything about it. Sometimes he preaches in Portuguese. His
performance of the marriage ceremony, I also witnessed. It was very
impressive. He always addresses the young couple before the ceremony; and
besides, has interviews with both in private before the union, at which I
understand he talks very seriously to them about their duties as husband
and wife, and also to God and Israel. His charities are disputed akin
to Jew & Christian. During the epidemic of small pox last year, when the other
clergy fled for their lives, he was at the bedsides of white, Black colored, administering medicines, pecuniary relief (in which the government gave

him carte blanche to draw) spiritual consolation, offering up prayer at the
instance of Christian sufferers, and helping occasionally with his own hands,
to put the dear in their coffins. He is highly respected by the Dutch Government.
His stipend is paid by the state, not by the Synagogue. I did not preach at Curaçao,
for the following reason. A requisition, respectably signed was sent to the Mahamad,
that I should preach. The mahamad sent for the Chacham?, and asked him if he had
any objection to me. On his answering, none, they told him that his pulpit would be
occupied by me the following Sabbath. To this, he replies, he would not object,
provided the mahamad asked his permission to have the pulpit so occupied. This
they refused to do, but sent me an intimation by letter that they would be happy
if I would comply with the request of the Congregation. Having been informed
of what had taken place, I declined, in my reply, to give an affirmative answer,
as the letter from the mahamad did not state expressly that the Chacham's?,
permission to occupy his pulpit had been obtained; but on receiving their assurance
that he had sanctioned it, I would be happy to comply with their request.
This led to another communication implying that I wished to dictate to them,
and informing me that the matter was at an end. Tho this I answered, disclaiming
most solemnly any intention of dictating to them the line of conduct they should
pursue, but adding that the line of conduct I had to pursue, agreeably to the
rules of good breeding and social etiquette which ? every obtained wherever
civilization and refinement existed, was not to occupy any pulpit until
I received the permission of the party to whom it rightfully belonged. In
a postscript, I said that being a stranger they would pardon me for declining any
further correspondence on the subject. There is a board called the Conseijo deo
Anciannos, consisting of past Presidents, which acts as a court of Review of,
or appeal from, the acts of the mahamad. To this board, the proceedings in the
matter were submitted a few days after, and out of 15 members present, 14
decided that the pulpit could at no time be occupied without the previous

consent and permission of the chacham. The dissentient? was the brother
of the President. To the chacham's honor I must state that he waited
personally on 7 or 8 of the most influential and wealthy of these A?
and, knowing the resentment they felt at the indignity put upon him by the
mahamad, as well as apprehending violence in the debate, exacted from them
a solemn pledge that they would keep away from the sitting, otherwise their
number would have swelled the notes condemnatory of the mahamad. This
question had been long pending, but not opportunity was afforded for settling it
before. The chacham's assertion that the pulpit belonged to him and my
firm support of his rights have now set the matter at rest, and strengthened
his position against the attempted encroachment of the mahamad. During
the progress of the discussion, I kept at home convinced that, in the influenced
passions of the Congregation against the mahamad, the latter would have been
bodily ejected from their seats in Synagogue, if I had gone up and down
and proved the impropriety of their action. I send you these particulars
in the event of your hearing any thing about it from the other side. The Revd.
Mr. Santcroos is the first מורינו הרב, he is the son-in-law of the chacham, and gives
instruction in Hebrew & Religion to the youth of the Congregation, in the מדרש
a certain number of hours p day; morning and evening. He is a very able
man. In his and his father-in-law's society, I spent much of the 18 days I
was at Curaçao. The wives of both are, I think, even more scrupulous than
the husbands. They are very pious and charitable women, and their kindness
to orphan children most touching. No shop or store is open among our on Sabbath or Holy day; even the second days are strictly kept.
Their rejoicings, as weddings, circumcisions, consecration of deadlings? are
indeed joyous, whilst their mournings are sad and melancholy. The abattons
or butcheries are out of the town, and they have, if I mistake not, two Shoctim
and two Shomeim over whom, as well as the butcher, the Chacham keeps a
most watchful eye. The Chazan, the Revd. Mr. Cardozo, altho' 73 years of age
shows in his decline what he must have been in his prime. He reads the
service and Parashah with fine musical intonation and accurately
grammatical pronunciation. The Synagogue is a fine old building,
but the centre is spoiled by the hugeness and massiveness of the pillars
which intercept the view and prevent the eye from taking in the bold proportions
of the interior at a glance. The ladies' galleries are latticed in true moorish
style. It is useless too look up, the eye of a lynx would fail to make out ?
the features of any fair one seated there. The Reading Desk and pulpit are
fine, the Hechal out of all proportion with the height of the building, and
the exterior of the building is hideous ugly; the western front positively
hideous. Divine service is performed twice a day, morning and evening
the whole week through, with always plenty of minyan. In the עומר

3 times; and in those weeks, the chacham lectures generally every
other evening, either from Scripture or from the mishna, always extemporaneously
without a note before him. Curaçao, in fine, so far as practical Judaism,
on old orthodox, rabbinical principles, is concerned, is very considerably
ahead of our sister Congregations in the other W. I. Islands, and need
not fear any comparison as regards adherence to the ancient landmarks of our revered religion.

I am waiting momently for the arrival of the steamer
from Europe, to receive the yea or nay to my ultimatum,
from the St. Thomas Congregation. My terms are, no specified
term of engagement, salary as fixed by the congregation, and
a pension, if after 10 years I am unable, or may be declared
incapable of, mentally or physically, of performing my duties.
This pension, modestly fixed at $600 ? is the pons
asinorum betwixt us. The good folks kick against it, whilst
ready to pension off their hitherto acting Chazan Maduro
tomorrow at $400 half his salary, (I only ask for a
third) and also admitting that no man will suit them
so well as I, combining as I do the capability of a
teacher, whom they require so much, with that of a chazan
and Preacher. The Government had told them plainly that
if they do not take ? me one, it will send them onea minister from Copenhagen,
with whom the Congregation Government will make a contract
whether its provisions be palatable or not. I have offered to
allow myself to be put on the same footing as other government
officers, at the instance of the governor. Today's mail

body.p:
will decide the point in dispute. If against me, I will, at
once take up the letter from Cincinnati, which I have
answered today. It only arrived on the 30th May, tho' written
in April, and I received it on the 5th June, the day I returned
home, but too late for replying to that it by that months
mail. I will not, at present, correspond with you on
the subject in deference to your wishes, but I expect Mr.
A. will. I have, at all events, opened up the subject
to him, and communicated how I am at this moment
situated with the St. Thos. Cong. It will be a trying
position for any man, with such opponents as silent that
and wise. Yet it is worth holding for that sake alone.
But what will principally deter me is the present
unsettled state of the country. Were I to take it, I
would not keep any school, as I would have enough to do with men of giant intellect, without being bothered
with teaching children. I am afraid, the mail will be closed
before the European steamer arrives, and I will have to
wait for the next monthly American steamer, as no dependance, can be placed on sailing vessels.

I deeply sympathize with you on the death
of your old aunt Mrs. Rehine, כבודו. The Revd. Mr. Myers
is just at my elbow, and begs me to say he will take an
early opportunity of writing you, that he sent you some
newspapers, and desires his kinds regards. The same to
J., Mrs. N. and Mrs. S. and with apologies for not answering
your letters more fully, which I will do next time, and
also hoping that my long Meguillah may not
